properties.name: Washun Niya
properties.popupContent: Washun Niya (Breathing Hole) is named after an entrance to a complex system of convoluted passageways that connects this world to the underworld. In traditional Lakotan cosmology, the earth is shaped like a great disk—or a saucer—that is thick at its center and tapers to a thin edge around its rim.

properties.name: Pte Taliyapa
properties.popupContent: Pte Tatiyopa (Buffalo Doorway) is located along the southeastern perimeter of an ancient racetrack that encircles the Black Hills. The racetrack is the geological remnant of an epic race between all the animals in the Lakotan world.

properties.name: Fort Laramie
properties.popupContent:
Fort Laramie, established in 1834 at the junction of the North Platte and Laramie Rivers, began as a trading post called Fort William. It served as a major hub for trading buffalo robes with Lakotans and Cheyenneans. In 1849, the U.S. military purchased the post, renaming it Fort Laramie, to protect miners and other emigrants heading west. The fort became a key stop for settlers, with up to 200,000 visitors during its peak.

The 1851 Horse Creek Treaty, negotiated at Fort Laramie, aimed to establish peace and protect Native hunting grounds from the encroachment of settlers. When violence broke out again during the 1860s, another treaty council was convened at Fort Laramie. When it was ratified, the 1868 Treaty set aside a large tract of unceded land, including the Black Hills, for the "absolute and undisturbed use and occupation" of the Lakotan people. Despite this, the U.S. soon began violating the terms of its own treaty, culminating in a brutal massacre at Wounded Knee, wherein the United States killed nearly three hundred unarmed Lakotans. Earlier that same year, in March 1890, Fort Laramie was abandoned and sold.

properties.name: Fort Fetterman
properties.popupContent:
Fort Fetterman was established in the summer of 1867 on the south bank of the North Platte River. Named after Captain William J. Fetterman, the fort served as a supply post and staging ground for military excursions into Lakotan Treaty Lands. Despite its strategic role, it was plagued by harsh winters and desertions were common.

Following the 1868 Treaty of Fort Laramie, Fort Fetterman became the northernmost outpost encroaching on unceded Lakotan territory (also known as Article 16 lands). It played a pivotal role in Plains Indians Wars of the mid-1870s, and served as headquarters for General George Crook's campaigns, including the Battle of Powder River, the Battle of Prairie Dog Creek, the Battle of the Rosebud, and the Dull Knife Fight. The fort was abandoned by the military in 1882, and after a brief period as a bustling town, it faded into obscurity.

properties.name: Camp Robinson
properties.popupContent:
Camp Robinson–named after Lieutenant Levi Robinson–was established in 1874 to guard the nearby Red Cloud Agency. The Camp also guarded the Sidney-Deadwood Trail to the Black Hills, and had the difficult task of keeping prospectors out following Custer’s 1874 expedition.

Following his surrender at the Red Cloud Agency in 1877, Crazy Horse and his people were housed in encampments by Camp Robinson. When General Crook ordered his arrest in September of 1877, Crazy Horse resisted. He was bayoneted and died at Camp Robinson.

That same year, 933 Northern Cheyenne and 4 Arapahoe people also surrendered at Camp Robinson. They were sent to the Cheyenne-Arapaho reservation down south, but a group of 150 Northern Cheyenne under Dull Knife left due to starvation and disease. They were recaptured and held at Camp Robinson, where the army withheld food, fuel and sanitary privileges in an attempt to force them back south. In 1879, the Cheyenne resisted; they broke out of their barracks, shooting the guards and fleeing. This became known as the Cheyenne Breakout.

By the 1880s, the fort had become the most important in the region. Its busiest years were in WW2, when it became a pack mule training site. The fort was decommissioned in 1947.
